comments.commentBody: I think not.
Focus, discipline, sacrifice, committment, and intensity are all their own rewards.

While America's economy is healing gradually, the recovery is still fragile. The Export-Import Bank increases U.S. employment and improves our balance of payments. The agency's activities also return $1 billion annually to the Treasury, reducing our national deficit. Shuttering the Export-Import Bank is madness-- something we can ill-afford.

Re-authorization of the Export-Import Bank has supporters across the political spectrum, ranging from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce to labor organizations. Please write to your Representative and Senators urging re-authorization of the Bank. To make it even easier, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has an online form that you can use.

Things are tough enough without our shooting ourselves in the foot.

The 10,000 hour rule supposedly shows that 80% of the difference between elite professionals and good amateurs is practice. I don't think that this is true, but even if it were, that still leaves 20% in talent variation and it's that 20% that makes all the difference. That is the 20% that coaches look for. Pure, physical talent (or musical or intellectual) is hard to find. The world is full of people who try hard, but that's not enough. Not very many people have "it." Talent can be wasted, it can be curtailed, it can be mismanaged, but it cannot be taught and that's why it's so exciting.
One extremely talented musician described his ability as something "that just comes easily to me."  This is as good a definition of gifted as I've ever heard. Talent will out.

What about those eco-friendly latrines with special bacteria that dispose the waist. I remember visiting one. I think it was in a camping area near mount Rushmore, when I visited it around 1997. There was educational signs proudly describing it's advantages and potential...

It's about time the public universities start to see some scrutiny after all the press and attempts to discredit and shut down for-profit colleges. As a sector the for-profits serve about 12% of all students yet they are demonized (in general) by the press and the politicians.

Over 40% of all students are in community colleges and their overall results are very poor, but generally not discussed. They have graduation rates on average of about 25% to complete a two year degree, measured over a 3 year period.

Also it is never mentioned that each year state and local taxpayers pay approximately $75 billion to fund the operating losses of public universities (both 2-year and 4-year).

I am always amazed by the lack of accountability regarding these large public organizations. The make big corporations look like angels (which they are not).

Right on all counts, but the really big issue is guns.  There are millions of people who really believe that only republicans are not coming to take their guns away.  And as their "right" to "bear arms" is the most important right that has ever been conceived, that trumps any economic or health impacts that might come their way with republicans in office.  It's that bad.

Living in harmony with nature, without upsetting the balance, is a zen-like goal sought by native Americans and other cultures throughout history. We have qualified it with a very large "somewhat". Then again, nature itself is an ongoing adversarial process and things, conditions and circumstances are ever changing. We've largely abandoned the humble notion of "take what you need and leave the rest" for an arrogant and shortsighted fascination with our clever technologies, rarely planning for the preservation and renewal of our own devices, much the less the word around them that enables and supports them, and therefor us. Nature has provided us with many warnings and not just a few consequences, yet we largely ignore them, instead worshiping the autonomy and omniscience of free markets. Some of us already know, and in the end the rest will learn, that it's Mother Nature that makes the corrections that count. Mother Nature will carry on and civilizations will endure, even if they're cockroaches and dung beetles instead of humans. There is no perfect static balance, as I mentioned, it's an ongoing process. It's not a mystery so obscure that we can't unfold it for our and everything else's benefit, but that takes a dose of humility and a world view far less egocentric than that required for those building altars to the almighty dollar, and a timeline broader than merely here and now.

It seems that whenever we find a new solution to a human problem, we suffer from unforeseen consequences. We eradicate a 'harmful species' like the wolf and we upset the balance. Without predators to balance their numbers, their prey's population explodes. The deer population becomes unamanageable and Lyme's disease emerges.
We develop chemical fertilizers and pesticides to solve world hunger and lose the bees we need to pollinate the very crops we are fertilizing.
We've developed new organisms using recombinant DNA (GMO's) and the scientists assure us these plants and microbes are 'safe'.
At the risk of sounding like a Luddite, 'We've heard that before".
We still have a lot to learn if we're to avoid killing off ourselves and our fellow species on this planet. Even when we think we've thought of everything that could go wrong, we just aren't as smart as we think.
When facts dispute conventional "wisdom", the dispute becomes political rather than scientific.
40 million years!!! That can't be right, the earth is only 6 thousand years old. ;-)

Once again, the effect of our short sighted and greedy demands wreak havoc on a species that has existed and thrived for over 40 millions years! We should be ashamed and use this as yet another wake up call. Really? Why is this such a difficult concept for us to grasp?

The demise of the honeybee can be traced to a single, big problem:  human beings.  Look at the source of your disparate "causes".  They are one and the same:  human interference.  We know not what we do.  And we're next.

This is absolutely true.  We do not know what complex chemical interplays (environmental/medical) may be contributing to the many visible perturbations in human health -- from autism, to cancer, to chronic fatigue syndrome, to obesity and many more.  Our chemical experiments may be wreaking havoc not only on our biosphere but on ourselves.  I have been almost completely and possibly permanently disabled by a short course of ciproflaxcin antibiotic -- often apparently benign, in me and many others toxic  What chemical, genetic, medical exposures pre-disposed me to such a fate?  The bees are a warning to us all.

The fact of "unforeseen connections" that you mention is the very thing we need to address! Why are they unforeseen? Why do we not routinely require testing of the effects of the ten or fifteen most commonly concurrently used drugs? Especially in the most vulnerable populations -- the elderly and children? We know enough to do better . . . but we don't force the issue, whether for motives of profit or for our own convenience.

On a related front: why do we allow Monsanto free rein to destroy our precious environment? Were we consulted on this -- most vital -- question?

Why do we allow the practices of Big Agriculture to continue if we KNOW they destroy variation among native species?

It is convenient -- but not natural -- to have strawberries on the grocer's shelf any month of the year. No matter that they are tasteless and nearly rotten after their gas-guzzling trip from drought-stricken California. It seems to me that we sacrifice "doing what we know to be right" -- without any help from any theist belief! -- for the twin evils of (1) convenience and (2) a deliberate unwillingness to confront what we already know and act upon it (a kind of moral spinelessness).

Thank you for this wise essay. It introduces two important concepts: One. how does synergy or accumulating effects lead us far from any clear understanding of how we perturb the system? And two, how does a natural system buffer and protect what we have perturbed?

Your analogy to medicine is apt. Often we understand drug-drug interactions involving two drugs used in combination, but rarely are there studies evaluating three drugs in combination, and for four forget about it. Then people come to their doctor on 16 or 20 drugs!

As a physician I find it is hard to sell the idea that less intervention might yield better health, but often it does. We are so interdependent on forces we ignore or dismiss, until some catastrophe confronts us. Hopefully then we can change in time, but I worry that the unforeseen connections we sever inadvertently will be our undoing.

This article needs to be brought to the attention of the President.
The collapse of Bees is a precursor to the eventual collapse of mankind.
This is an extremely important article!

The answer to your second and third questions is most likely, "No". The Koch brothers and other billionaires in our country aren't in the bee business. Their world is a world of numbers, money and bottom lines, not nature.
I, too, do not have a "chemlawn", but a short meadow, teaming with many species of flowering plants to feed pollinators.  My neighbors hate it...

We have a lot of trees, gardens, very little grass and a mechanical push mower. We have become accustomed to the helpful people who drop by to tell us we could actually cut down the trees, flatten out the undulations and plant grass. On otherwise beautiful days the neighborhood will have hours of the unbelievable roar of lawnmowers to maintain the lifeless appearance of empty green parking lots. Are these great green patches that take so much and return so little an historic statement of wealth - look at the rich land I can afford to waste? Without the trees we would miss the beauty and privacy but more than anything we would miss the birds. Presently all we miss out on is the untold cost of pesticides.

But how can one resist the images of emerald-green lawns shown on TV and the reassuring and commandingly manly voice of the pesticide hawker who promises that his product will kill all those nasty bugs and protect your family??!!  The message is truly sickening, and we individuals can each do our part by letting children know how sick and dangerous such advertising is.  Pesticides and perfect lawns need to be the 'new cigarettes.'

Most people are too lazy and brainwashed to do the right thing.  We are one of the only families in our neighborhood who do not use pesticides on our lawn.  We have clover, violets and wild flowers.  Grass is another mono crop that is killing the natural variety needed for healthy ecosystems.
I'd wager a large number of bees could be brought back by merely planting ovwe golf courses with fields of wild flowers.
Sounds to me that we should adopt permaculture as much as possible to minimize or even avoid those issues. Instead of mono-culture, our fields and gardens should maximize species richness.

I have no faith that elected officials will pay any attention. They pay too much attention to corporate sponsors and lobbys to have any brain room left over for such a thing as long term survival for us all.

We have to pay attention.

If we have any speck of dirt to plant something, plant something bee friendly that is certified as not being treated with pesticides.

Engage in guerilla gardening. Read up on planting times, and scatter seeds of bee friendly plants on road edges, railway edges, and vacant areas, even if they aren't yours. This is not as silly as it sounds, and can be a lot of fun.

Try to buy stuff that was not made from monocultures. Try to buy stuff that comes from plants that didn't have coated seeds.

Support environmental groups that oppose all the things that kill bees (and the birds that eat them are dying too). Oppose those groups who disparage the environmental groups.

Since we can't seem to elect officials that will a darned thing, we need to take back the power. If only one person per block took out their lawn and planted wildflowers - how beautiful would that be? If everyone on the block made a big wide flowerbed beside their small lawn and planted the wildflowers, how much more beautiful would that be?

Thank you Dr. Winston, best wishes with your work.

We are interlopers.  Our cultivating civilization  has been around no more than 10,000 years. Contrast this with bees who have lived in harmony with their environment for 40 million. Their societies are complex  with language and cooperation and yet we humans assume that we control everything and can even manipulate bee populations that have never needed our help to survive.  If we in our arrogance assuming that our world is only ours to play with, do we as a species deserve to survive?  Well, nature in its own wisdom will decide this question as it does with all species and I hope we learn our lessons well before it is too late..

Scientists have found that the windblown dust from seeds treated with systemic fungicides at planting time to prevent possible rotting of seedlings in case there is a cold wet spring has been found to be a significant cause of bee deaths. http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/pesticides-linked-to-bee-deaths-must-b...
We must be far more judicious with our use of systemics, if not banning them altogether. We ought to restore the practice of letting fields lie fallow for a season or two and planting mixed hedgerows to encourage wildlife. It would be better to lose some crops. We can afford it. Forty percent of food grown ends up being thrown out.

"A USDA study released Tuesday reports that 31% of bee colonies died this past winter. Here, a honey collection in Homestead, Fla., last month."

http://napoleonlive.info/did-you-know/importance-of-bees-colony-collapse/

WA Spitzer … Did you bother to check out Mark Winston's credentials? Like … beginning with his author ID at the bottom of the article??? This is not a "just" an informed citizen penning an OP-ED piece … this is a man who earned his PhD from Harvard more than 30 years ago, and has been working with honeybees (and other social insects) ever since. He was trained at Harvard by some of the world's experts on social insects (look up E.O. Wilson and Bert Hölldobler for a start), and is an acknowledged expert in the field. Whatever you think of the article, and despite your ignorance of his credentials, questioning his integrity is inexcusable. And what, incidentally, are YOUR credentials?

Charles- I'm so glad that you pointed this out. It is sad with our total lack of basic scientific understanding that we don't know the difference between mutation, hybridization and gene manipulation and willingly promote this ignorance. One cannot cross a carrot with a fish through non genetic manipulation no matter how hard one tries. The lack of basic scientific understanding in a good portion of our population is truly alarming and extremely dangerous. The willingness to dismiss data that they personally don't agree with is dangerous as well. Our ignorance and willful dismissal of evidence that is contrary to our "beliefs" will cause the demise of us all.
My husband works for a utility company that sprayed round-up as weed control several years ago. Nothing is growing in this sprayed spot yet. They now use bleach instead which has far less impact as far as residual effects. It may require a couple applications a year but at least it's not forever toxic, poisoning the ground so nothing will ever grow again. How can this practice be acceptable to any of us? Where is our shared responsibility in being good stewards of the only environment we have to live in? Where is our concern for the collective good, the future of our children and subsequent generations? Our selfishness and self absorption will be the death of us all.
I have used vinegar to kill weeds, which is even less toxic to the enviroment than bleach.

sharon and Charles: I'm quite aware of what most people mean by the term GMO. (I am a cancer biologist in my current profession and we deal with genetic modifications all the time.) My point is that we have been modifying plant and animal genes for ages and in ways that also carry significant risks. In this sense the current trend to limit the definition of genetic modification to mean interspecies exchanges of genetic material is too limited. Most of the more common negative claims about the risks of GMOs have little or no evidence to support them, whereas the risks of inbreeding and crop monocultures have been known for centuries.

I'm not suggesting we ignore the risks of GMOs, but to sharon's point about scientific literacy I am suggesting that we take a more comprehensive look at how we have modified our food sources in ways that put us a big risks. It's all too easy to just jump on the latest trend (e.g. anti-GMO) and feel like we're being good citizens.

I wish academics who write articles in the mainstream press would at least cite sources for the important claims. Academics can be just as self-serving as leaders of big business; perhaps more so because they are paid far less.

That said, I think the author makes a very important argument for the value of species diversity. When I hear people get up in arms about GMOs I usually point out at almost ALL food in the supermarket is genetically modified in the extreme. All one needs to do the believe this is to look at the nearest wild relative of any animal or vegetable. Millennia of inbreeding and planting vast amounts of land with the same inbred crops cannot be a good thing. Having the majority of our food sources come from such limited genetic diversity cannot help but place those sources at much higher risk for collapse.

In any ecosystem, complexity and diversity creates stability.

Not all bees sting! There are thousands of species, even underground & solitary bees.

Public schools here are establishing veggie gardens in the playground & installing stingless native bees in hives to pollinate.

Australia's Aborigines have long raided hives for a sweet treat without needing to smoke the bees first.

There are many stingless US native bees too, so everyone can safely have a hive & enjoy bees.
I buy some plants from these stores and all kinds of bees come to my garden. You just have to know which ones to buy. They don't have to be natives necessarily.

We plant natives when we garden in the Catskills, and have seen more bees than ever.  And we have never been stung.  We also buy plants locally, never from big box stores.  It may be a nearly pathetic move, but the happy bees speak volumes.

What's worse, we are now seeking to monocrop other liveable planets out there with humans, by attempting to send out human genetic material that can be brought to life in its new worlds. I just don't get the point. Why is it so important to us to fill other worlds with human bodies, especially when we know how destructive we are as a species?

Look at those Iron railings - what a fabulous building!

I hope that when Mayor De Blasio takes his upcoming trip to Italy, he will learn that European cities have a much higher degree of preservation that NYC.

Perhaps he will figure out that constantly ripping your city down, and replacing everything with low quality modern architecture, designed only to pack the greatest possible square footage into a building, leads to a reduction in tourism.

In a city where pleasing real estate developers and construction unions is, "priority one", the occasional preservation of a building such as Grand Central Terminal can be considered an accidental event - we need 100 Jackie Kennedy's to save NYC, but we have none now.
